summary: Acute respiratory disease reached the status of a Public Health Emergency of International re Concern (1).

Address correspondence to: fernando.kay@utsouthwestern.edu s On January 30, 2020, the International Health Regulations Emergency Committee s concluded that the outbreak of 2019 novel coronavirus (COVID-19, formerly 2019-nCoV)

The spotlight of this Radiology: Cardiothoracic Imaging issue exposes the wider spectrum of radiologic manifestations of the COVID-19 acute respiratory disease that can be encountered on images of the chest.
Ng et al (5) examine the clinical and radiologic presentation of 21 patients with confirmed COVID-19 from Chinese centers in Shenzhen and Hong Kong.
The article demonstrates the spectrum of radiologic presentations s and illustrates the growing role of CT in evaluation of patients with COVID-19 when compared to past coronavirus outbreak.

Kong and Agarwal (10) report a series of three unrelated cases of COVID-19 pneumonia presenting with a spectrum of findings on chest radiograph and CT, varying from the commonly seen ground-glass p opacities and consolidation, to patterns that include crazy paving and reversed halo, suggesting organizing pneumonia as the underlying mechanism of lung injury (11, 12).
Wu et al (13) show the temporal evolution on CT of a patient with COVID-19 infection, presenting with radiologic findings resembling organizing pneumonia.
A review of the results published by Chung et al (8) reveals that rounded lung opacities can be present in up to 33% of the chest CT of symptomatic patients with COVID-19.

In a thoughtprovoking report, Liu et al (18) illustrate the spectrum of severity within a familial cluster of p husband, wife, and son infected with COVID-19, varying from a normal study, to subtle centrilobular nodules, and the more common picture with multifocal ground-glass opacities.
Statement on the second meeting of the International Health Regulations (2005) Emergency Committee regarding the outbreak of novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV).
